title: If I file for a Legal Separation in California and later reconcile my marriage, can I stop the separation process.
question: If my spouse has 30 days to respond and agrees to the separation, how much time before we have to reconcile or dissolve the marriage.
question_tags: Divorce,Alternatives to divorce,Legal separation and divorce,Dividing debts in a divorce,Community property in divorce,Divorce petitions and complaints,Divorce and bankruptcy,Bankruptcy,Debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Divorce and family,Family law
answers: There is no time limit. Be aware, however, that, generally, f you reconcile, debts and earnings during the separation period regain their community property character.

Until the court enters a judgment of legal separation, or dissolution, you can stop the action, if the other party agrees. If you reconcile, you can agree to dismiss the case completely, and the court will not come looking for you to make you finish it. You should speak to an experienced family law attorney about the steps of the process.

Generally there is no clock ticking or time limit to either dissolve the marriage or reconcile after filing a divorce petition. California law encourages the preservation of marriages and the Court has no desire for your spouse and you to remain legally separated, when in fact both of you have reconciled. Procedural, there are many things you can do during your Legal Separation action to if you two decide to reconcile down the line. For example, you can request a dismissal during the proceeding if you reconcile. Another example would be a motion to vacate the judgment after your spouse reconciled and after a judgment of separation.
